Project1.name: Portfolio website
Project1.description: I made this website to host my portfolio and some descriptions
Project1.workDescription: Solo dev venture. I wanted to show that I can use preact signals, which was left incomplete in the showtime squad project. A portfolio website seemed like a useful way to do that.
Project1.challenges: My greatest challenge lied in employing the same techniques and technologies I didn't have time to properly implement for my part of the work in the showtime squad school project, namely preact signals. My first approach was too complicated in nature, but I'm really satisfied with the finished product

Project2.name: ALKU-application
Project2.description: A web application for tracking and centralising outsourced billing for Oulu University ICT Department.
Project2.tech: JAVA, JDBC, Vaadin & Quarkus frameworks, RedHat OpenShift(OS), Azure Pipelines

tasks.task1: Learning and understanding previously done work, especially the statemachine at the core
tasks.task2: Implement logic for Lasku table based on design document
tasks.task3: Carry logic to frontend representation of lasku table data
tasks.task4: Implement state change for the entity on the frontend and save the data properly to backend database
tasks.task5: Study how to move product to production on OS via Azure Pipelines
tasks.task7: Implement more features and fix previous inaccuracies to better represent the requirements specification, including more precise access control.
tasks.task8: Update documentation based on discussed and approved changes.
tasks.task9: Make sure next developer for the project will have the necessary testing data, environmental variables, etc. for project continuation.

Project2.workDescription: I came into the project midway, had about 1 month together with the previous trainees who built the project up to that point, before I was left as the sole developer for the application. I enjoyed the work environment and my co-workers were awesome. My mentor was Vesa Jokikokko.
Project2.challenges: The first challenge was to communicate my vision for the finished product to the other group members, which I started with a diagram for the state machine. The greatest challenge for me was using the database information in the frontend, as I had had little to no experience with Qt signals and slots before this project. I had some trouble with getting the data to show up properly, but the process was very educational. I can say that I learned a lot about debugging and using Qt, including signals and slots.

Project3.name: The Mobile Swiss Army App
Project3.description: A multi-purpose mobile app with several functionalities deveoped from the ground up, including spirit level, area calculator, and speedometer.
Project3.tech: React Native, several basic sublibraries for React Native

tasks.task1: Jointly ascertain the project requirements for the project from the requirements definition document
tasks.task2: Jointly determine individual areas of responsibility.
tasks.task4: Utilize pair programming principles while developing
tasks.task5: Utilize mobile device's telemetry data to math and configure the spirit level and compass.
tasks.task7: Devise a tape measure with freehand implementation, and try my best to get it to work using physics equations and device location data. I was unsuccessful, but learned a lot about mobile device limitations.
tasks.task8: Help with the creation of area calculation algorithm that accounts for angles over 180Â° for the plot area calculator.
tasks.task9: Jointly make and do the presentation.

Project3.workDescription: School project, I enjoyed developing the app with the team I joined. I did a little bit of everything, and felt the workloads and challenges were well balanced.
Project3.challenges: The highest challenge was obviously the free movement tape measure, which was unsuccesful in the end. The other problem I had was with the magnetometer, which I realised came from the magnet in my phone cover disrupting the sensors.

Project4.name: Showtime-Squad
Project4.description: Website for movies and tv shows. Made as a 2nd year school project
Project4.tech: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React, preact, Java, Spring, postgreSQL

tasks.task1: Plan the database structure and ER diagram
tasks.task3: Structure API calls between TMDB and our backend
tasks.task6: Postman testing and documentation for user created lists
tasks.task7: Miscaellaneous bugfixes and helping others with their tasks

Project4.workDescription: My first responsibility was to create the database structure and ER diagram. I then proceeded to design the navbar and structure the API calls between TMDB and our backend. I also designed the backend for user created lists, but didn't have time to finish the frontend for it. In between my tasks I helped others a little with their tasks and did miscellaneous bugfixes. There was also a discarded plan for more detailed automated testing for the database, which was dropped.
Project4.challenges: I chose to start with the ER diagram because I had had some trouble with relation databases previously. I found the task easier than I thought it would be, and I'm gkad having done it. The biggest challenge was the user created lists, which I didn't have time to finish. I had to learn a lot about how to structure the backend for it with JAVA and Spring, and I didn't have time to finish the frontend for it. I'm still happy with the work I did on it, and I'm glad I got to learn more about JAVA and Spring.

Project5.name: BankSimul
Project5.description: ATM simulator. Made as a 1st year school group project
Project5.role: Fullstack Developer and de facto project coordinator

tasks.task1: Jointly ascertain the project requirements for the project from the requirements definition document
tasks.task3: Design database structure and ER diagram
tasks.task4: Create part of the relation tables for the database with SQL
tasks.task5: Jointly create backend for the ATM with JavaScript from example code
tasks.task6: Frontend account balance and event log pages with Qt (C++)
tasks.task7: Coordinate the project and help others with their tasks

Project5.workDescription: I had the most clear vision of the finished product, so I was the one who designed the state machine for the ATM. We designed the database structure and ER diagram together. For the frontend I was responsible for the balance and event log pages. I also helped others with their tasks and did miscellaneous bugfixes. We kind of forgot to do a proper readme.
Project5.challenges: The first challenge was to communicate my vision for the finished product to the other group members, which I started with a diagram for the state machine. The greatest challenge for me was using the database information in the frontend, as I had had little to no experience with Qt signals and slots before this project. I had some trouble with getting the data to show up properly, but the process was very educational. I can say that I learned a lot about debugging and using Qt, including signals and slots.

Project6.name: Brighty (because it has bright lights)
Project6.description: Speed test game. Made as a 1st year school group project. No github repository. Provided in images an assembly example I modified from the course material. Text in pictures is in Finnish.

tasks.task1: Jointly choose the project idea to work on
tasks.task2: Jointly determine the hardware requirements and budget for the project
tasks.task3: Design state machine for the game logic
tasks.task4: Assign workloads to other team members and coordinate the project
tasks.task5: Create an interrupt based timer for the game logic implementing provided assembly examples
tasks.task6: Create the game logic with Arduino C++
tasks.task7: Design and create a Simon Says side game with Arduino C++

Project6.workDescription: As the first group project, we had to learn how to work together. The leadership role fell onto me, as I was the one who suggested the project idea, and I was the one who designed the state machine for the game logic. I think I did a decent job balancing the workloads according to each member's interests and capabilities. I also created the interrupt based timer for the game logic, based on provided assembly examples. Since our project was ahead of schedule, I quickly designed and implemented a Simon Says game. I directed and helped the other group members throughout the project, and I think we did a great job. We also designed the presentation and poster together. The project had no github repository, as we didn't use any version control.
Project6.challenges: Stepping into the leadership role did not come naturally to me, but I think I did a good job. I had to learn how to balance the workloads and how to direct the other group members. I learned some good techniques for more efficient vision communication. Implementing the interrupt based timer seemed daunting at first, but I managed to do it with the help of the provided assembly examples. Directing the other group members and alleviating their concerns was less of a challenge than I thought it would be, which I can wholeheartedly attribute to the good group dynamic we had.
